    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Ftroubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Ftroubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Ftroubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if.md?ref=132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4",
    "patch": "@@ -1,74 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Troubleshoot Conditional Access using the What If tool\n-description: Where to find what Conditional Access policies were applied and why\n-ms.service: entra-id\n-ms.subservice: conditional-access\n-ms.topic: troubleshooting\n-ms.date: 08/13/2024\n-ms.author: joflore\n-author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n-manager: dougeby\n-ms.reviewer: calebb\n-ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n----\n-# Troubleshooting Conditional Access using the What If tool\n-\n-The [What If tool](what-if-tool.md) in Conditional Access is powerful when trying to understand why a policy was or wasn't applied to a user in a specific circumstance or if a policy would apply in a known state.\n-\n-Find the What If tool in the **Microsoft Entra admin center** > **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Policies** > **What If**.\n-\n-![Screenshot of the Conditional Access What If tool at its default state.](./media/troubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if/conditional-access-what-if-tool.png)\n-\n-## Gathering information\n-\n-The What If tool needs only a **User** or **Workload identity** to get started.\n-\n-The following additional information is optional but helps narrow the scope for specific cases:\n-\n-* Cloud apps, actions, or authentication context\n-* IP address\n-* Country/region\n-* Device platform\n-* Client apps\n-* Device state\n-* Sign-in risk\n-* User risk level\n-* Service principal risk (Preview)\n-* Filter for devices\n-\n-This information can be gathered from the user, their device, or the Microsoft Entra sign-in log.\n-\n-## Generating results\n-\n-Enter the criteria gathered in the previous section, and select **What If** to generate a list of results.\n-\n-At any point, select **Reset** to clear any criteria input and return to the default state.\n-\n-## Evaluating results\n-\n-### Policies that will apply\n-\n-This list shows which Conditional Access policies would apply given the conditions. The list includes both the grant and session controls that apply including policies in report-only mode. Examples include requiring multifactor authentication to access a specific application.\n-\n-### Policies that won't apply\n-\n-This list shows Conditional Access policies that wouldn't apply if the conditions applied. The list includes any policies and the reason why they don't apply including policies in report-only mode. Examples include users and groups that might be excluded from a policy.\n-\n-## Use case\n-\n-Many organizations create policies based on network locations, allowing trusted locations and blocking locations where access isn't allowed.\n-\n-To validate that a configuration is appropriate, an admin can use the What If tool to mimic access from a location that should be allowed and from a location that should be denied.\n-\n-[![Screenshot of the What If tool showing results with Block access.](./media/troubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if/conditional-access-what-if-results.png)](./media/troubleshoot-conditional-access-what-if/conditional-access-what-if-results.png#lightbox)\n-\n-In this instance, the user is blocked from accessing any cloud app on their trip to North Korea because Contoso blocks access from that location.\n-\n-This test can be expanded to include other data points to narrow the scope.\n-\n-## Related content\n-\n-* [What is Conditional Access report-only mode?](concept-conditional-access-report-only.md)\n-* [What is Microsoft Entra ID Protection?](~/id-protection/overview-identity-protection.md)\n-* [What is a device identity?](~/identity/devices/overview.md)\n-* [How it works: Microsoft Entra multifactor authentication](~/identity/authentication/concept-mfa-howitworks.md)"
  },

ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a comprehensive restructuring of the Microsoft Entra security documentation. The core `configure-security.md` file has been significantly revised, moving from a pillar-based approach to a more organised grouping of security recommendations. This change is accompanied by the creation of six new markdown files, each dedicated to a specific Zero Trust security pillar (Protect identities and secrets, Protect tenants and isolate production systems, Protect networks, Protect engineering systems, Monitor and detect cyberthreats, and Accelerate response and remediation), providing detailed guidance within each area. Additionally, the table of contents for the fundamentals section has been updated to reflect these changes, and a redirection has been added for the 'What If' tool documentation. Some minor updates have also been made to the Conditional Access documentation, including date changes and clarifying wording.

ai_summary.Messages: {"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [ { "sha": "96bba57a39436f2b364fcbe44c409120668d41c7", "filename": "docs/id-protection/concept-identity-protection-risks.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 28, "deletions": 10, "changes": 38, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-identity-protection-risks.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-identity-protection-risks.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-identity-protection-risks.md?ref=132a03c5f979a167eff2528d5bcd0d202dfe8db4", "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ description: Explore the full list of risk detections and their corresponding ri\n ms.service: entra-id-protection\n \n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 08/06/2025\n+ms.date: 09/11/2025\n \n author: shlipsey3\n ms.author: sarahlipsey\n@@ -78,7 +78,9 @@ Select a risk detection from the list to view the description of the risk detect\n This detection is discovered using information provided by [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/anomaly-detection-policy#activity-from-anonymous-ip-addresses). This detection identifies that users were active from an IP address identified as an anonymous proxy IP address. \n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2 *and* Microsoft 365 E5, Enterprise Mobility + Security E5, or standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- License requirement:\n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Additional risk detected (sign-in) \n \n@@ -127,7 +129,9 @@ The algorithm ignores obvious \"false positives\" contributing to the impossible t\n This detection is discovered using information provided by [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/anomaly-detection-policy#impossible-travel). This detection identifies user activities (in a single or multiple sessions) originating from geographically distant locations within a time period shorter than the time it takes to travel from the first location to the second. This risk might indicate that a different user is using the same credentials. \n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2 *and* Microsoft 365 E5, Enterprise Mobility + Security E5, or standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- License requirement: \n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Malicious IP address \n \n@@ -142,7 +146,9 @@ This detection indicates sign-in from a malicious IP address. An IP address is c\n This detection is discovered using information provided by [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/investigate-anomaly-alerts#unusual-file-access-by-user). This detection looks at your environment and triggers alerts when users access multiple files from Microsoft SharePoint Online or Microsoft OneDrive. An alert is triggered only if the number of accessed files is uncommon for the user and the files might contain sensitive information. \n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2 *and* Microsoft 365 E5, Enterprise Mobility + Security E5, or standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- License requirement:\n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Microsoft Entra threat intelligence (sign-in) \n \n@@ -157,7 +163,9 @@ Microsoft Entra threat intelligence indicates user activity that is unusual for\n This detection is discovered using information provided by [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/anomaly-detection-policy#activity-from-infrequent-country). This detection considers past activity locations to determine new and infrequent locations. The anomaly detection engine stores information about previous locations used by users in the organization. \n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2 *and* Microsoft 365 E5, Enterprise Mobility + Security E5, or standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- License requirement:\n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Password spray \n \n@@ -180,14 +188,18 @@ Suspicious browser detection indicates anomalous behavior based on suspicious si\n This detection is discovered using information provided by [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/anomaly-detection-policy#suspicious-inbox-forwarding). This detection looks for suspicious email forwarding rules, for example, if a user created an inbox rule that forwards a copy of all emails to an external address. \n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2 *and* Microsoft 365 E5, Enterprise Mobility + Security E5, or standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- License requirement:\n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Suspicious inbox manipulation rules \n \n This detection is discovered using information provided by [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/anomaly-detection-policy#suspicious-inbox-manipulation-rules). This detection looks at your environment and triggers alerts when suspicious rules that delete or move messages or folders are set on a user's inbox. This detection might indicate: a user's account is compromised, messages are being intentionally hidden, and the mailbox is being used to distribute spam or malware in your organization. \n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2 *and* Microsoft 365 E5, Enterprise Mobility + Security E5, or standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+- License requirement: \n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Token issuer anomaly \n \n@@ -248,7 +260,9 @@ This risk detection baselines normal administrative user behavior in Microsoft E\n Also referred to as Adversary in the Middle, this high precision detection is triggered when an authentication session is linked to a malicious reverse proxy. In this kind of attack, the adversary can intercept the user's credentials, including tokens issued to the user. The Microsoft Security Research team uses Microsoft 365 Defender for Office to capture the identified risk and raises the user to **High** risk. We recommend administrators manually investigate the user when this detection is triggered to ensure the risk is cleared. Clearing this risk might require secure password reset or revocation of existing sessions.\n \n - Calculated offline\n-- License requirement: Microsoft Entra ID P2\n+- License requirement:\n+ - Microsoft Entra ID P2 and a standalone license for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps\n+ - Microsoft 365 E5 with Enterprise Mobility + Security E5\n \n ### Leaked credentials \n \n@@ -271,7 +285,9 @@ This risk detection type indicates user activity that is unusual for the user or\n This risk detection type is discovered using information provided by Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MDE). A Primary Refresh Token (PRT) is a key artifact of Microsoft Entra authentication on Windows 10, Windows Server 2016, and later versions, iOS, and Android devices. A PRT is a JSON Web Token (JWT) issued to Microsoft first-party token brokers to enable single sign-on (SSO) across the applications used on those devices. Attackers can attempt to access this resource to move laterally into an organization or perform credential theft. ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates Microsoft Entra ID documentation. Key changes include:

*   Refining the description and license requirements for various risk detections in Microsoft Entra ID Protection.
*   Expanding the SCIM Validator section in the SCIM provisioning guide to detail validations for creating, updating, and disabling users.
*   Adding troubleshooting steps and a comparison table for Certificate Revocation List (CRL) signature validation errors in Certificate-Based Authentication (CBA).
*   Inserting cross-references to the new CRL troubleshooting article within several other CBA-related articles, including those for mobile devices, smart cards, limitations, and migration.
